handDesc.p: Halantas. Final T is a slightly reduced ta without a tail, e.g. l5 apālayaT; a clear example is l30 bhr̥T. Final N is a reduced and simplified na, with a straight vertical stem that extends only up to the headline, e.g. l7 māsāN. Rare final K occurs in l26 satyavāK, but it is indistinct in my scanned estampage. It may consist of the lower part of a regular ka (an oval with two arms), and perhaps a single upward tail above that. Rare final Ṭ in l40 rāṬ is also unclear; it appears to be much like ṭa, but may have a vertical tail.

Original punctuation marks. The opening symbol is wholly unclear in the scanned rubbing; Lakshmana Rao describes it as a floral device. Regular punctuation marks are plain vertical bars, the same height as or slightly shorter than a character body.

Other palaeographic observations. Lakshmana Rao (138-139) gives a very detailed analysis of the palaeography of this grant and its companion CalE40 . Its main points are summarised here. The vowel marker of ā is sometimes an upward stroke, e.g. l1 mā and nā, l8 ṭṭā, l23 hā, l24 jñā, l39 jā. An alternative form of the marker for u is used in e.g. l1 pu; this is used in conjunction with m, p and y. The two forms appear close by in line 37, and a third form is found in l22 kalpataru; this is used with r and k. All three forms appear in line 38. Dependent e may be attached to the foot on the left, or on top of the character. Anusvāra is never used before dental and retroflex stops, where the homorganic nasal appears instead.

app.note: While the exact wording of the lost text cannot be reconstructed and its meaning is beyond doubt, the words I propose seem most likely on the basis of the Eastern Cālukya corpus in its present stage. The words tad-anuja-yuvarāja-vikramāditya-bhūpateḥ occur in two grants of Amma II, in both cases followed by the words proposed here. In other versions of the genealogy, the phrasing deviates from the text preserved here, e.g. tad-anuja-yuvarāja-bhūbhr̥d-ātmajaś cālukya-bhīma-; tad-anuja-yuvarāja-vikramāditya-narapātmajaḥ̣ cālukya-bhīma-; tad-anuja-vikramādityātmajaś cālukya-bhīmas; tad-anujasya labdhayauvarājyasya vikramāditasya sutaś cālukya-bhīmas.

I adopt Lakshmana Rao's reading because the scanned estampage is illegible; there, I can only make out most of ya and part of ssa (affected by the break in the plate), then nothing before mma in the next word. Since a noun seems to be missing here, I wonder if the correct reading is in fact yas suto bhavad. If not, then the text should be emended, e.g. yas sutas samabhavad (eyeskip omission?).

The emendation proposed by Lakshmana Rao is probably a typo and his intend must have been vinirgamayya. In the scanned estampage it seems definitely possible that the repha is in fact there above gga, so I prefer the reading that does not require emendation.

Lakshmana Rao assumes that his reading dāyān means dāyādān, which I do not find convincing at all. The problematic character is completely indistinct in the rubbing. Lakshmana Rao's editor (probably Hirananda Sastri) tentatively proposes in a footnote to read it as je, which I adopt provisionally. If this reading is correct, it permits construing either jitvā+jeyān or jitvā+ajeyān, of which I slightly prefer the latter because the former is extremely bland.

Lakshmana Rao's reading fits the context and metre well and I do not have a better one to offer, so I adopt it. However, I find it unlikely (though not impossible) that the ka he prints as unclear could have been squeezed into the end of line 21 before the rim, and therefore prefer to show it as a restored omission. Further, at least in my scan, what is visible of the first character in line 22 does not indicate I.

Lakshmana Rao's emendation is quite certainly correct. I am not so certain of his reading, which I adopt while noting that I can only make out kya in the scanned estampage, with plenty of noise above. What Lakshmana Rao saw as a repha and an ā mātrā may perhaps be an interlineal addition of the characters kr̥ṣṭa.
Again I adopt Lakshmana Rao's reading with some misgivings. I would prefer to read -mahimā, and this seems possible from the scan.

This character is completely indistinct in the scan, but it does not seem to include a subscript m. I wonder if there is a typo in Lakshmana Rao's edition; his actual reading may in fact have been saṁmaḥ, as there is a dot above the fairly large space between sa and ma.

Though Lakshmana Rao's edition shows only dots here, the characters shown as unclear can probably be read at least tentatively in the original plates. (Those shown as lost here have been mostly broken off, but some vestiges of their upper parts may remain.) Since Lakshmana Rao did have the originals and appears to have been intimately familiar with the script, my tentative reading and restoration may be completely off the mark.
I adopt Lakshmana Rao's reading. The second character is illegible in the scan, but I believe it is more likely in the context to be rai than re, possibly followed by r nna

I accept Lakshmana Rao's note that the characters dhīmanto gu are inscribed over an erasure. I see no indication of this in the scanned rubbing. From gu onward, there is much background noise, but the characters are quite clear up to that point.

The size of this lacuna does not appear to be more than four characters. Something may have been omitted by the scribe here, or there may be a correction in which six characters were inscribed over a smaller number of earlier ones. It should be possible to get at least a tentative reading from the original plates.

The reading is more than plausible in the context, yet (though there is some damage here), prā seems to be impossible. The character appears to be pyā or ptyā (where the primary consonant is also uncertain), and may require emendation to prā. Alternatively, Lakshmana Rao may be wrong in his reading of the preceding characters (which are illegible in my scan), and what we have here is °ādhīṇya (for °ādhīnya), preceded by a word ending in -ti.

div.p: According to Lakshmana Rao, the last letter of the seal legend (śa) is below the rest, to the proper right of the boar emblem. The seal is rather weathered and the published photo is not too clear, so I can only guess where this may be.

The second plate is broken in a roughly vertical line affecting all text lines, and with a small fragment between the two lost, affecting the first three lines of 2r and the last three lines of 2r. I see no need to encode the fragments in the edition.

As Lakshmana Rao observes, the karṇa-rājākhya-vallabha in line 17 is the Rāṣṭrakūṭa king Kṛṣṇa III. He assumes that our poet wrongly Sanskritised his Prakritic name Kaṇṇa to Karṇa. This is possible, but given that he prints rṇa as unclear in his edition, there may be no need for such an assumption. In the scanned rubbing, only the upper part of ṇ is distinct, with a small curved vertical stroke on top of the right wing and a large blotch of damage below the character. It is possible that the small curved stroke is not a repha, and there may have been a subscript consonant. Thus, both kaṇṇa and kaṇḥa seem to be possible readings. Lakshmana Rao may have seen more of rṇa in the original, but this is not certain given his tendency to indicate an unclear reading only when something is barely legible or wholly lost.

The caesura is obscured by sandhi in v2a and b (sragdharā, second caesura in both cases) and 11c (śārdūlavikrīḍita), vāgm:īndra. There is a flat yatibhaṅga in verse 8 (śārdūlavikrīḍita), pāda c, splitting ane:kam. Also in 9b (śārdūlavikrīḍita), splitting san:tr̥pti. Also in 11b, splitting mukt:ā-hāra. Verse 11 (śārdūlavikrīḍita) has a compound across pādas ab.

Reported in 17A/1920-192116 with discussion in 90-91. Edited from inked impressions (made by G. Venkoba Rao) and from the original plates by K. V. Lakshmana Rao (137-1481), with translation and facsimile. The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on a collation of Lakshmana Rao's edition with his facsimiles.The facsimiles, as scanned, are illegible in many places. I rely primarily on Lakshmana Rao's readings, and generally mark up unclear only where he did so, assuming that the originals were much better legible. However, he seems not to distinguish unclear readings from restorations in his editions, so it is quite possible that all or most of the "unclear" readings are in fact restorations, and many of the "clear" readings are unclear even in the original. Consulting the printed facsimile may also help.
